briefdescription.para: Global per-device cache capacity in sectors.

detaileddescription.para: This limit is applied to every cache instance. Increase with care; it impacts memory consumption linearly (one sector buffer per entry).

briefdescription.para: Compare two cache entries by LBA (hashmap comparator).

detaileddescription.para: Expects pointers to block_cache_entry_t. Returns negative, zero, or positive according to standard qsort-style ordering.

simplesect.para: <0 if a < b, 0 if equal, >0 if a > b.

briefdescription.para: Hash a cache entry by LBA (hashmap hasher).

detaileddescription.para: Uses SipHash over the 64-bit LBA stored in the entry.

briefdescription.para: Evict the globally oldest entry from the cache.

detaileddescription.para: Pops the LRU head, removes the entry from the hashmap if present, and frees its sector buffer. No-op if the LRU is empty.

briefdescription.para: Create a new cache for a storage device.

simplesect.para: Pointer to cache instance, or NULL on error.

briefdescription.para: Destroy a cache and free all associated resources.

parameterdescription.para: Pointer to cache pointer; set to NULL on return.

briefdescription.para: Compute a sector count that covers a byte length.

detaileddescription.para: Rounds up bytes to a whole number of sector_size units. Used to iterate multi-sector operations at sector granularity.

simplesect.para: Number of sectors covering bytes (at least 1).

memberdef.argsstring: (block_cache_t *c, uint64_t lba, uint32_t bytes, unsigned char *out)
memberdef.name: block_cache_read

briefdescription.para: Read bytes from a cached device.

detaileddescription.para: Granularity is per sector; the cache works in multiples of the deviceâ€™s block size. Reads hitting the cache are served immediately; misses are read from the device and then cached.

simplesect.para: 1 on success, 0 on failure (fs_set_error() is set).

memberdef.argsstring: (block_cache_t *c, uint64_t lba, uint32_t bytes, const unsigned char *src)
memberdef.name: block_cache_write

briefdescription.para: Write bytes through to a cached device.

detaileddescription.para: Writes are always passed to the device. The cache is updated (write-allocate) so subsequent reads will hit.

simplesect.para: 1 on success, 0 on failure (fs_set_error() is set).

briefdescription.para: Invalidate all entries in a cache.

detaileddescription.para: Useful when a device is reset or forcibly changed.

briefdescription.para: O(1) block cache with LRU eviction.

detaileddescription.para: This module implements a sector/block cache designed for use with storage devices. It combines a hashmap (for direct lookup) with an LRU queue (for eviction ordering).

listitem.para: Each cached LBA is stored in a hashmap for O(1) lookup.
The eviction policy is Least Recently Used (LRU).

Instead of maintaining a "perfect" LRU list, the queue only stores LBA values. When an LBA is re-inserted, a new entry is appended to the tail of the list; the old entry is left in place. On eviction, the cache checks if the LBA still exists in the hashmap before removing it.

sect2.title: Complexity
sect2.para: By tolerating duplicates in the LRU queue and validating at eviction time, we avoid costly O(n) operations to move entries within the queue. The result is a strictly constant-time cache for both reads and writes.

listitem.para: Memory overhead: The LRU queue may contain duplicate LBAs. This increases memory use slightly, but only linearly with cache size.

Eviction precision: Because of duplicates, eviction order is approximate LRU rather than perfect. In practice this has negligible impact on hit rates and avoids the cost of O(n) list traversal or heap reordering.

sect2.title: Summary
sect2.para: This design achieves the optimal theoretical complexity for a block cache: O(1) lookup, O(1) insert, and O(1) eviction. It is robust against pointer invalidation bugs by never storing raw pointers from the hashmap in the LRU queue, and it guarantees bounded, predictable performance even under heavy load.
